comments.text:
+B-Swizzle Raps Actually, he said we did NOT evolve from chimps but we did 
evolve. This is a complicated statement because there is Macro-evolution 
and Micro-evolution. Macro-evolution is of the mindset that every creature 
evolved from a lessor creature. The Darwinian concept is like a tree 
branching out new species from one species, however, evidence does not 
support this theory. In fact there were more different kinds of species 
millions of years ago than there are now. Macro-evolution just does NOT 
happen, however, micro-evolution can be observed as small adaptations to 
the environment. For years mankind has been searching for the 'missing 
link' to connect Neanderthal to Cro-Magnon. Thanks to genetic sequencing we 
discovered that there is no missing link. Neanderthal was a completely 
different kind of human, now extinct, with no genetic markers comparable to 
Cro-Magnon (from whom we descended from). So Darwin's theory is invalid, 
even by Darwin's own standards which he included in his book (see 
Irreversible Complexity). It takes more "religion" to believe in Evolution 
(macro) than to believe in Intelligent Design. However, I am agnostic so 
I'm more inclined to believe that an entire race of Beings designed us 
rather than one Supreme Being.

comments.text:
The most accurate answer is probably "chimp-like ancestor." There are 
actually some features of chimps that are more derivative than ours (e.g., 
spine, feet), meaning that they changed more over time compared to our 
theoretical divergence. Basically, from the neck up, humans changed more, 
but from the neck down, chimps have changed more.

When we look at specimens like Lucy and Ardi, we get a better idea of what 
our ancestor looks like, but we can't really know for certain what our 
common ancestor truly looks like because that kind of thing isn't really 
well-defined. We can look at each specimen individually, but we can't 
create a well-defined group that allows us to really say, "These specimens 
belong to the same species."

To maybe get away from the topic a little, any given species is more of a 
useful name than an actual, well-defined group. Sure, we can look at 
several different kinds of apes and say this is a chimp, baboon, etc., but 
when you stretch this over millions of years and leave behind only 
skeletons/fossils, it gets a bit more complicated and much more difficult. 
Is this skull heavily distorted, or is it really a different kind of ape? 
Does this particular bone warrant a new classification within this species? 
What is a mutation and what is something that belongs to something we may 
be able to call a species? These problems all arise partly because the 
sample size is relatively small, and some of the details can be considered 
to be relatively trivial. It's also a bit of a philosophical question, 
which I'm not really qualified to comment on.
comments.author: WMDistraction

top_comment.text:
The JFK one is wrong… He did say that he was a donut. The thing is, Germans 
are so used to people making this mistake that they obviously understood 
what he was saying. 

Ich bin ein Berliner = I'm a Berliner (which is also a donut)
Ich bin Berliner = I'm Berliner (Person from Berlin)
Ich bin Studentin = I'm student (female)
Ich bin eine Studentin = I'm a student (female) but, like I said, 
technically not correct. Germans still obviously understand this, it's just 
not correct. So yes, JFK DID make a mistake. I know this because I 
currently live here and my German prof in America taught us about these 
weird usages of articles by using this example. ﻿

Regarding storing batteries in the freezer, here's what Energizer said.  

Energizer:
1. Is it a good idea to store batteries in a refrigerator or freezer? 

No, storage in a refrigerator or freezer is not required or recommended for 
batteries produced today. Cold temperature storage can in fact harm 
batteries if condensation results in corroded contacts or label or seal 
damage due to extreme temperature storage. To maximize performance and 
shelf life, store batteries at normal room temperatures (68°F to 78°F or 
20°C to 25°C) with moderated humidity levels (35 to 65% RH).

Read more at http://www.snopes.com/oldwives/battery.asp#qqiQ3XWzg3XGARmm.99

A Chest of Drawers depending on your dialect in English and your speed 
could turn the 'of' sound into an 'er' which would lead to a chest 'er 
drawers.  Which then turns into Chester Drawers.  It is simply slang 
dialect developing as people talk.  After generations it sounds more like a 
style of drawers rather than a definition.  I grew up saying Chester 
drawers but knowing it was a Chest of drawers. 

Another famous one is kegger.  It is a keg of beer but due to dialect 
influence has become a kegger beer or simply 'kegger' to refer to a party.

top_comment.text:
I may be wrong on this as I'm not bilingual and still have a lot to learn 
about the German language but with the Kennedy 'ich bin ein berliner' quote 
I think it can be translated either way. What he meant was 'berliner' in 
the sense of being someone who lives in Berlin but the word also translates 
to 'doughnut'. When meaning someone who lives in Berlin, grammatically 
'ein' would not be used which is why it was translated the other way. 
Although, as it is one word with two meanings, everyone would know what he 
meant, the translation is still correct as it's a matter of grammar rather 
than the words themselves. Please feel free to correct me if I'm wrong!﻿
top_comment.author: Lucy Tregidon

comments.text:
Actually These were the original sentences:

1.“Two thousand years ago the proudest boast was 'Civis Romanum sum‘ (I'm a 
Roman citzen). Today, in the world of freedom, the proudest boast is ‚Ich 
bin ein Berliner‘.”
„Vor zweitausend Jahren war der stolzeste Satz ‚Ich bin ein Bürger Roms‘. 
Heute, in der Welt der Freiheit, ist der stolzeste Satz ‚Ich bin ein 
Berliner‘.“

2. “All free men, wherever they may live, are citizens of Berlin, and, 
therefore, as a free man, I take pride in the words ‘Ich bin ein Berliner!’”
„Alle freien Menschen, wo immer sie leben mögen, sind Bürger Berlins, und 
deshalb bin ich als freier Mensch stolz darauf, sagen zu können ‚Ich bin 
ein Berliner‘!“

So, no mix up possible, unless you're a complete moron. ;)
comments.author: cadeeja67

comments.text:
This was a major topic of discussion in my German class, and my teacher 
(who is from Germany and was alive when he said it) said that while some 
Germans do call a certain kind of jelly doughnut a Berliner, there wasn't 
any actual confusion at the time. People did make a joke out of it though, 
because when translated directly it can mean 'I am a jelly doughnut'. But 
not really.
comments.author: summer Q.

comments.text:
It isn't a grammar thing in german. In german you can't just say "ich bin 
berliner" you have to add the "ein". Also, Berliner doesn't translate to 
doughnut. A doughnut like food is called Berliner everywhere in Germany, 
except for in Berlin where they call them "Berliner Pfannkuchen". I doubt 
any of the people in Berlin back then misunderstood him, it's just that it 
sounds like that when you translate it directly instead of looking at the 
meaning.

captions.text:
Hi I'm John Green this is mental_floss,
and 1. Vikings never wore horns on their helmets...at

least not until an 1876 staging of Wagner's
Opera The Ring of the Nibelung is the first
of 50 myths I'm about to bust for you.

You know iron maidens? The medieval
torture device that inspired the fourth-best

heavy metal band of all time? Yeah, they were
fictional.

3. Marie Antoinette never said "Let
them eat cake" when told peasants were
starving due to lack of bread.

4. And while we\'92re on the topic of
French royal women who were parted from their

heads, Anne Boleyn did not have eleven fingers,
or at least most historians don't think so.

5. The American Declaration of Independence
was not signed on July 4 1776. It was signed
on August 2, 1776,

6. Also, not to harsh on your buzz,
but the U.S. constitution was not written
on hemp paper but on parchment.

7. Napoleon did not have a Napoleon
Complex, as he was five seven, slightly above
average height for his time.

8. Albert Einstein didn't fail math
at school, and when he was showed a newspaper

column claiming he had, Einstein responded,
"Before I was fifteen I had mastered differential

and integral calculus." Einstein did hook
up with his cousin, though, so that's something.

9. John F Kennedy did not say, "I
 am a jelly doughnut" when he said "Ich

bin Ein Berliner." No one in Berlin was
confused on that day about what Kennedy was
saying.
10. Sushi does not mean raw fish; it means "sour rice."

11. Placing metal in a microwave doesn't
ruin the microwave. I mean, it's definitely

a bad idea, but look, we just microwaved this
tin foil and now in the smoldering remains
I am microwaving a hot pocket.

12. The word "crap" is not derived
from the great Thomas Crapper, who helped

give us indoor plumbing. Sadly, "crap"
just comes from Latin, like all the other
words.

13. 420 is not the Los Angeles police
code for marijuana possession. Police Code

420 just means juvenile disturbance, which
only SOMETIMES involves marijuana possession.

14. The Great Wall of China is not the
only man-made object visible from space. For

one thing, many man-made objects are visible
from space. For another thing, the Great Wall
of China is not among them.

15. There's no such thing as an elephant
graveyard where old elephants go to die. When

elephants are ready to die, they just do it,
like the rest of us.

16. The 1992 book SHARKS DON'T GET
CANCER led to an increase in people using

ground-up shark cartilage to treat cancer,
but 1. That doesn't work, and 2. Sharks
do get cancer.

17. Chameleons don't primarily change
color to camouflage. It helps them regulate

their temperature and it's a way of communicating.
\fs24 \

18. Throwing rice at weddings does not
lead to birds eating that rice and then the

rice expanding in their stomachs and the birds
exploding. This has just never happened once
in all of human history....or bird history.

19. An earthworm does not become two
earthworms when you cut it in half. If it's

lucky, the part with the mouth survives and
you're left with one, smaller earthworm.

But most likely you'll end up with two
dead earthworms.

20. Humans have more than five senses,
including a sense of time, acceleration, and

limb position. The five senses were made up
by Aristotle, with whom I have a longstanding

and public feud, and as usual, he was wrong
and I am right and shut up about how he isn\'92t
here to defend himself.

21. Shaving does not cause hair to grow
back thicker or coarser, no matter where you're shaving.

22. Your fingernails do't keep growing
after you die.

23. If you swallow your gum, it will
not stick in your stomach for seven years.

It goes through your body just the same as
anything else you eat. Except batteries.
Don't. Eat. Batteries.

24. People don't use only 10% of
their brains. William James seems to have
coined this one, but he was speaking figuratively.

25. You can't catch warts from toads.
But you can get warts from other people, which
is why I always say: Only socialize with Toads.

26. A penny dropped from the Empire
State building will not kill someone if it

lands on their head. The terminal velocity
of a penny is between 30 and 50 miles per

hour, not fast enough to kill anyone. Also,
if you drop a penny from the top of the Empire

State Building, it will land like three stories
below you, because the building is shaped like this.

27. Abner Doubleday did not invent baseball
and in fact never claimed to have invented baseball.

28. Caesar salad was not invented by
Julius Caesar but for its inventor, Caesar

Cardini, who supposedly invented the salad
in Tijuana, Mexico in 1924.

29. Puff the Magic Dragon is not about
Marijuana. As Mary of Peter Paul and Mary

put it, "Believe me, if he wanted to write
a song about marijuana, he would've written
a song about marijuana."

30. Sherlock Holmes never said "Elementary,
my Dear Watson," nor did

31. anyone ever say "Play it again,
Sam" in Casablanca,

32. Sarah Palin never said, "I can
see Russia from my house," and

33. Al Gore never said, "I invented
the Internet." Oh, and

34. FOR THE LOVE OF GOD RON BURGUNDY
NEVER SAID WELL THAT ESCALATED QUICKLY. He
said boy, that escalated quickly.
Okay gotta speed up.
35. Danishes are from Austria, not Denmark.

36. Humans didn't evolve from chimps;
we share an ancestor...but we did evolve.

37. It's a chest OF drawers, not
a chester drawers, as I learned when I was 28 years old.
38. If you can replace you're with You Are, contract; otherwise, don't.

39. The Italian libertine is Don Juan,
but in Byron's epic poem, he is Don Juan
Rhymes With Ruin.

40. You would not explode in the vacuum
of space.

41. No one was burned at the stake during
the Salem Witch Trials; 19 people were hanged
and one was crushed with stones but NO BURNING.

42. Chinese fortune cookies are Californian
not Chinese.

43. Neither blondes nor redheads are
about to go extinct.

44. No one died during the chariot race
sequence of
Ben Hur.

45. Mussolini didn\'92t make the trains
run on time;

46. Storing batteries in the freezer
does not improve their performance;

47. THERE IS NO NEED TO REFRIGERATE
PEANUT BUTTER, unless it's all natural
or organic or whatever;

48. Walt Disney is not cryogenically
frozen;

49. Fidel Castro was never given a tryout
by the Washington Senators or any other baseball
team and

50. Famed sexologist Dr. Ruth was not
a sniper in the Israeli army? What? She was?

Wow. Fine, then. 50. Julia Child was not actually
a spy for the United States during World War 2.
SHE WAS? OH I GIVE UP.
